claim:
Consider the following background information: A 4-year-old boy presents for a routine checkup. The patient’s parents say he was doing well until a few weeks ago at which time he started to complain of daily abdominal cramps and occasional muscle pains. His mother also noticed that he has been less active than usual. The parents deny any complaints of headaches or convulsions. The family lives together in a house built in 1950. The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min and respirations are 20/min. Abdominal exam shows mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and normal bowel sounds. The patient’s height, weight, and head circumference are normal. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 7 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 72 Lead level (capillary blood) 15 mcg/dL Lead level (venous blood) 60 mcg/dL Findings on a peripheral blood smear are shown in the image.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The best treatment option for this patient is Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA), also known as succimer.

supporting.text: Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) is a chelating agent specifically approved for treating lead poisoning in children with blood lead levels ≥45 mcg/dL, which matches this patient's venous lead level of 60 mcg/dL.

attacks.text: Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) is a chelating agent specifically approved for treating lead poisoning in children with blood lead levels ≥45 mcg/dL, which matches this patient's venous lead level of 60 mcg/dL.

DMSA is not recommended for asymptomatic children with blood lead levels below 45 mcg/dL, and this patient's capillary blood lead level is only 15 mcg/dL, which may indicate a false venous reading or contamination.
Venous blood lead levels are more accurate than capillary levels for diagnosing lead poisoning, and the patient's venous level of 60 mcg/dL is well above the threshold for DMSA treatment.

The patient's symptoms (abdominal cramps, muscle pains, and lethargy) are non-specific and could be caused by conditions other than lead poisoning, such as viral infections or nutritional deficiencies.
The patient's microcytic anemia (Hb 7 g/dL, MCV 72) is highly suggestive of lead poisoning, especially given the elevated venous lead level and the history of living in an older home.
